Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means a lot to your father.” My heart tightened. This ceremony was more than a ritual—it was a thread tying generations together, and my parents expected me to honor it, to show I valued our roots. But my laptop chimed with a reminder: “Quarterly roadmap meeting in 30 minutes.” My manager had been clear—my estimates would shape the entire project timeline. The team was counting on me to be precise, to show leadership and technical insight. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of family pride on one side and professional responsibility on the other. My mind raced with questions: If I focus on the ceremony, will I let my team down? If I prioritize work, will I disappoint my parents and break tradition? The pressure built inside me, a knot of guilt and anxiety, as I sat frozen between two worlds, unable to move.
